moves.7... h6: Black's passive play gives white an advantage.
moves.8. a3:
With the idea of b4.

Or h3.
moves.8... b6: Here computer analysis likes 9. b4 for white, but I saw a chance to attack the weak knight on c6.
moves.9. e5: My hope is to get the queen to e4 with a dual threat on h7 and c6.
moves.9... Nd7: Now white has a strong advantage.
moves.12. Bxh6: Now if 12... dxe5 13. Bxf8 Bxf8 14. d5
moves.13... Rxf6:
Now white needs to be careful.  Although 14. Bg5 is winning, there are some tricky tactics that follow.

14. Bg5 Nxd4 (14... Na5 is also a good move for black.) 15. Qxd4 Rxf3 16. Bxe7 (16. gxf3 Bxg5 is a problem.) 16... Rxd3 17. Qxd3 Qxe7 18. Qxg6+ Kf8 and white is still winning.
moves.14. Qg4: Getting the queen out of the line of fire of the b7 bishop.
moves.14... Qe8: Here white has to avoid 15. Bg5 Rxf3 16. gxf3 Bxg5 17. Qxg5 Nxd4 and suddenly white is losing.
moves.15. Nb5: Bringing either rook to e1 is probably a little better.
moves.15... Rc8: Black can defend a little better with 15... Qf7 16. Rae1 Qh7
moves.17. Bg5:
The black position collapses. 

Now 17... Rf5 18. Nh4 (Which is stronger than Bxf5) Qf7 19. Nxg6 Qxg6 20. Rxe6 Qxe6 21. Bxf5
moves.19... Kg7: Now playing d5 with the idea of Nbd4 might be the strongest.
moves.21... Rd8 22. Qh3: Now black can survive a little longer with  22... Bc8 23. Qh4 Qd7 24. Ne6+ Qxe6 (24... Kf7 25. Nd5 Nfxd5 26. Qh7+ Kf6 (26... Ke8 27. Bxg6+ Nxg6 28. Nxc7#) 27. Qh8+ Kf7 (27... Bg7 28. Qxg7# ) 28. Ng5+ Ke8 29. Bxg6#) 25. Rxe6 Bxe6
moves.23... Kf7: Now stockfish prefers to build up the attack with moves like Re2, Re3, Qh8 or d5.  Instead white plays ...
moves.24... Qxd8:
Now  25. Re6 is the strongest with the threat of Rxf6+ 

25. Re6 Bc8 26. Rxf6+ Kxf6 27. Qh7 Bg7 28. Nd5+ Kf7 (28... Nxd5 29. Qxg6+ Ke7 30. Qxg7+ Ke6 31. Re1+) 29. Re1 Nf5 (29... Nxd5 30. Bxg6+ Kf8 (30... Kf6 31. Qh4+) 31. cxd5 Bd7 32. Re3) 30. Bxf5 Bxf5 31. Re7+
moves.26. Ne4:
This is a tactical error. White thinks that he can win by trading pieces.  Stockfish thinks that a more positional approach is much stronger: 26. Ne2 (Headed to e6) Bc8 27. Qe3 Qd7 28. d5 Qg4 29. Nf4 Nf5 30. Bxf5 Qxf5 31. h3 g5 32. Ne6+ Bxe6 33. Qxe6 Qxe6 34. Rxe6 Kf7 35. g4 Kg7 36. f4 Nh7 37. fxg5 Nxg5 38. Re8 (headed to c8.)

6. Qe3 Followed by Ne2 is the same idea.
moves.26... Nxe4:
Taking the knight is poison.

27. Re2 Nf6 28. Rfe1 Bc8 29. Qe3 White has a material and positional plus.
moves.27. Bxe4: Overlooking that now Bc8 traps the queen. Now if 27... Bc8 28. Qxc8 Qxc8 29. d5 and White is losing but barely hanging on.
moves.30. Rg4: Now if 30... Ne7 31. Ree4 [Or Re3] a5 (31... Qe8 32. Ref4) ( 31... Qc8 32. Rxg6+) 32. Ref4 Qe8 33. Qf6+ Kg8 34. Rh4 Bg7 35. Qe6+
moves.33. Qe5+: Now if Kg8, 34. Re3 is very strong with the idea of going to h3.
moves.33... Kh7: Slightly worse because the king no longer defends the bishop.
moves.34. Qe8: Now Qxe8 is met with Rxh4+.  Black resigns here.  If the game were to continue ...
moves.35. Re6:
The overloaded queen can no longer defend everything.

Now  35... Qg7 36. Rxh4+ Kg8 37. Rxg6
moves.36... Kg7 37. Qd7+: Of course, Qf7 is met with Rh7+.
